subject: Support packing cable presence sensor state into discrete sensor
commitMessage:
Support packing cable presence sensor state into discrete sensor

Tested: Make sure ipmitool gets the correct response
```
ipmitool sdr list event
cdfp[0-3]        | Event-Only        | ns
osfp             | Event-Only        | ns
osfp[1-2]        | Event-Only        | ns

ipmitool raw 0x4 0x2b 0x0
 00 03 00 00 00
```

Signed-off-by: Chu Lin <linchuyuan@google.com>
Change-Id: I30970fd40c210cd5ee05acc8a8b60661dff60db7

Is this available in dbus interface?
right, not sure why I couldn't find it before,
is this restriction in the spec?
Yes, I just updated the doc.

Update comment?

Is the cables SDR type 3?
can move the scope of this inside the statement.

do we need this?

Is this used somewhere else?
Yes it is used in both sdrutil.cpp and sensorcommands.cpp. Therefore, I promoted it from sensorcommands.cpp to sdrutil.hpp.
nit: the spacing does not match here?
do we never expect failure here?
We do. In the case of the failure, we just log the relavent error and return the initial value which indicates none of the cable is presenting.
you might want to add the interface add/remove with `/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/item`?
Since you're not mutating prefer string_view
explicitly capture what you want in your lambda
can this also be a string_view?
can't this block be vastly simplified if we just use a regular expression here with match groups?

static/inline constexpr instead?

Then coding standards apply , something like discreteSensorMaxStates

Also is MaxStates the right wording for this? MaxStates makes me think that a discrete sensor can have a maximum of 14 states whereas this is being used to describe how many discrete sensors can be represented by a record right?

this regex seems wrong.

According to this the following wouldn't be matched

/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/cables/myCable

and neither would this

/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/cables/myCable[0-10]


maybe this is a bit closer?

^([A-Za-z0-9\/_]+)(?:\[([0-9]+)-([0-9]+)\]){0,1}$

I'd play around with some regex checker to test it out first.

this looks like debug and seems like it'd spam the logs.
If so, please remove.
Forget to remove the debug print. Will have them removed.

^[\w\/]+\/(\w+)+(?:\[(\d{1,2})-(\d{1,2})\]){0,1}$

This seems to work well and separates the sensor name into group 1
range start (if present) into group 2
range end (if present) into group 3

used regex101.com as the checker.

Two things..

(1)can we put some description on what this regex should match on with some useful examples?
e.g
cable[0-3] would produce
group1=cable
group2=0
group3=3

cable2 would produce
group1=cable2
group2=empty, no match
group3=empty, no match


(2) The escape syntax in the regex doesn't look right to me. Can you please confirm that it does work?

In particular this part doesn't look like the right regex to me...
(?:\\[([0-9]+)-([0-9]+)\\])
particularly 

\\[

I was expecting this to be \[ to put the '[' literal in the regex..
\\[ 
looks like we're expecting the '\' literal followed by a range

I don't think search is what we want here. we want match right?
We want to match on the whole string, not a substring.

Don't think this logic is correct.

the match can be something like `cdfp0` and matches[2] and matches[3] will be empty.

I think in this case if a cable was named `cdfp0` then this will probably throw an exception.

To add

matches[2],[3] = EMPTY is the condition where we have something like cdfp0 and so that's actually the non-indexed case..

If the match fails then you have a malformed object path at which point you should give up and report an error?

friendly ping to +2 reviewers.

Anything else needed?
Chu, please address some of the current comments.

I need to wait for the final consent on https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/45997. This two CL goes hand in hand. I afraid if the other CL needs to be changed. This CL needs to be changed again.
